awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Core Support for the U.S. Hub of the Future Earth Secretariat
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides core support for the staff and activities of the US Hub of Future Earth Secretariat.  The Future Earth program seeks to coordinate international global change research to help accelerate transformations to sustainability through research and innovation. In this role, the US Hub of Future Earth serves as a convener that helps US researchers engage in research based on the co-design and co-production of knowledge and tools designed to help develop solutions to global environmental challenges such as fresh water security, coastal vulnerability, disaster risk reduction and resilience.  The program is supported by major U.S. agencies, under the interdisciplinary auspices of the U.S. Global Change Research Program.   Over the past several years, the US Hub has taken on activities that directly support the USGCRP and its member agencies.  These funds will be used to further engage the US research community in these developing efforts.

The Future Earth program is organized around three major themes: Dynamic Planet; Global Development; and Transformations toward Sustainability. Under the auspices of these three themes, the US Hub of the Future Earth Secretariat will support workshops and other efforts to foster the co-design of research to enhance transdisciplinary efforts to help develop solutions for many challenging societal issues. The US Hub will also develop programs and initiatives to educate the next generation of inter-disciplinary researchers and professionals on how to integrate global sustainability with human prosperity and will actively engage the public through an extensive communication and outreach effort.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Future Earth is a global network organization advancing transdisciplinary and sustainability science. The US Global Secretariat Hub (US Hub) is one of the eight offices of Future Earth?s distributed global Secretariat, and it leads several key functions, ranging from global communications, IT and finance, to coordination of the national committees and global research networks. During this reporting period, the US Hub also hosted the Interim Executive Director of Future Earth. In addition, the US Hub leads several international programs, such as the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress (SRI), the Anthropocene Magazine, and the Earth Leadership Program.

Key functions of the Future Earth Secretariat include Networks and Capacity, Research and Innovation, Communications, and Coordination. This grant enabled US Hub engagement with all of these functions. Below we describe each function and the role of this grant in supporting US Hub engagement.

 

Networks and Capacity:

The first SRI Congress, SRI2021, was held in Brisbane, Australia, and online, in June 2021, and it brought together over 2000 participants from more than 100 countries. Our free virtual pre-Congress events, called SRI Talks, engaged almost 700 people worldwide. SRI is rapidly emerging as the leading global meeting platform for sustainability science and innovation. Inclusivity is one of our core values: in 2021, we distributed over 500 participation scholarships for early career professionals and participants from low and middle income countries. The Congress was well-received: 94% of our post-Congress survey respondents said that they would attend the next SRI Congress, SRI2022. This enthusiasm was confirmed by the strong response to the SRI2022 call for session proposals, which attracted almost 250 submissions from nearly 50 countries. SRI2022 will take place at Future Africa at the University of Pretoria, South Africa, and online, in June 2022. The SRI Congress includes several training and capacity building opportunities, and the series is attracting sponsors supportive of its sustainability focus. All SRI2021 content is now open access, and the SRI2022 content will be made publicly available soon after the Congress.

The Earth Leadership Program is about to launch its first and the most diverse cohort to date. The program is also developing a long-term strategy and is further developing its role in advancing transdisciplinary research training, both in the US and internationally.

In addition, this grant enabled the coordination of the 19 Future Earth national committees, which advance sustainability and global change research in their respective countries. Key outcomes include increased connectivity within this diverse network and the inclusion of these committees in the Future Earth new global governance structure.

 

Research and Innovation:

The US Hub led the establishment of Future Earth as a founding partner in the Partnership for Resilience and Preparedness (PREP). This public-private collaboration, launched in September 2016, seeks to empower a data-driven approach to planning for and building climate resilience.

This grant also leveraged significant work and funding in the field of research and innovation, including the Earth Commission, which is a part of the Global Commons Alliance; Program for Early-stage Grants Advancing Sustainability Science (PEGASuS), funded by the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation and now in its fourth cycle; and support for the Belmont Forum in Collaborative Research Action development. Moreover, the US Hub provided liaison support for the 27 Future Earth Global Research Networks. 

 

Communications:

The US Hub continued to produce and distribute high-quality communications content through the various Future Earth channels. Over the past year, the Future Earth website received an average of 29,311 unique page views per month, with visitation from virtually every country in the world. 25% of the traffic came from the United States. The number of Future Earth newsletter subscribers has exceeded 8,500. Our new Member Portal is also growing.

Our open access Anthropocene Magazine also plays a growing role in translating scientific research findings to a broader audience: We have produced 1590+ articles in Anthropocene Magazine to date, and these articles reach 34,000 people by newsletter. 

 



Coordination:

The period covered by this report was significant for Future Earth. In response to an external evaluation report, Future Earth went through a comprehensive organizational transition process to improve its inclusivity, reach and impact. The US Hub played a key role in facilitating this transition, which resulted in a new, accessible governance structure and a more inclusive Secretariat, with representation from low and middle income countries.
